 - Monitoring the bidding behavior of other bidders: Keeping track of the bidding behavior of other bidders can help you determine when to enter a bidding war and when to drop out. If you notice that other bidders are consistently bidding high on certain items, it may be a sign that those items have a higher true value than your estimated value, and you may want to focus on other items.
 - Managing your budget: Given your total budget of $20000, it's essential to manage your budget carefully to ensure that you don't overspend on any single item. This may involve setting a maximum bid for each item based on your estimated value and your remaining budget.
 - Prioritizing items based on their potential profit: Based on your estimated values and the starting prices of the items, you can prioritize which items to bid on based on their potential profit. Items with a large difference between their estimated value and starting price may offer the greatest potential profit, while items with a smaller difference may not be worth bidding on.
 - Keeping a backup plan: In case you miss out on an item you were interested in, it's essential to have a backup plan. This may involve focusing on other items with a higher potential profit or adjusting your bidding strategy to account for unexpected bidding behavior from other bidders.

In this round, You may target some of these subgoals and guidance to improve your bidding strategy and action, in order to achieve your primary objective.
